section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: Hands-on programming section with exercises covering variable declaration, data types, and type operations in Python. Students will learn how to work with different data types, perform type conversions, and understand the fundamentals of Python's dynamic typing system.
learning_objectives: Declare and initialize variables in Python
Identify and work with basic data types (int, float, string, boolean)
Perform operations on different data types
Convert between data types using built-in functions
Use type checking to verify data types

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to declare variables, assign values, and understand Python's dynamic typing system.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables for your name, age, height, and favorite color. Assign appropriate values and print each variable. Then, reassign the age variable with a new value and print it again.
Use multiple assignment to create three variables (x, y, z) with values 10, 20, and 30 in a single line. Then swap the values of x and y without using a temporary variable.

lessons.lesson_title: Working with Numbers: Integers and Floats
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to perform mathematical operations using integers and floating-point numbers.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create a program that calculates the area of a rectangle (length * width) and the area of a circle (π * radius²). Use both integer and float values. Print the results with appropriate decimal places.

Test all arithmetic operators with both integers and floats. Create examples showing the difference between / (regular division) and // (floor division), and demonstrate the modulo operator with both positive and negative numbers.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create, modify, and extract information from strings using Python string methods.
key_topics: Common string methods (upper, lower, strip, split)

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create a string containing your full name. Write code to: 1) Convert it to uppercase, 2) Extract just the first name, 3) Count the number of vowels, 4) Replace spaces with underscores.
Write a program that takes a user's input sentence and formats it properly: capitalizes the first letter, ensures proper spacing, and adds a period at the end if missing.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to use boolean values and comparison operators to evaluate conditions.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables with different numeric and string values. Write expressions to test all comparison operators with these variables. Print both the expression and its result to understand the output.

Write expressions that combine comparison operations with logical operators to check: 1) If a number is between 10 and 20, 2) If a string contains 'python' (case insensitive) OR 'coding', 3) If a number is even AND positive.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to convert between different data types and check the type of variables.
key_topics: Built-in conversion functions (int(), float(), str(), bool())
Type checking with type() and isinstance()

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables of different types and practice converting them between types. Include cases that will fail (like converting 'hello' to int) and use try-except to handle the errors gracefully.

Write a program that accepts user input as strings and converts them to appropriate types. For example, ask for age (convert to int), height (convert to float), and whether they like programming (convert to bool). Validate the conversions and print the types of each variable.
